name: Quartz Albas
text_appearance:
Pilot is a human man in his late 20's. Further questioning suggests the pilot has been in constant nearlight travel for over 80 years in realtime.

Pilot's body is riddled with scars. His left arm is entirely mechanical, as is most of his left torso.

Hair is medium length, mostly black but with white on top. Often messy. Hair colors confirmed to be natural.

Has green eyes. Often accented with black eyeliner.

“It looks like Quartz does not want to bring any more attention to himself as an Albatross than is already there. Because of this, he has stored away the red garb associated with the Albatross for some green and white dress. I still think he looks a little too shiny, so I gave him grandpa’s grimy ol’ cloak for when he leaves that mech of his. It makes him look mysterious, and maybe even a bit threatening.”
notes:
- Quartz is very closed off as an individual, knowing he is a dangerous target. 
- He still carries his Albatross’ heart on his sleeve; try as he might, he cannot refrain from helping someone in need. He also has not forgotten his past as a Loyal Wing, as he still works quite well in group situations. However, due to the circumstances, Quartz has developed a bit of a habit of going off on his own.
- However, when he is in combat or a tough situation, Quartz is rather steeled. He may be tender-hearted but he harbors no qualms about killing, especially if it’s got anything to do with Harrison Armory.

- one thing has nagged at him constantly since hearing about the protocol. it's the feasibility of the whole situation. you don't doubt that the Standard had enough firepower, that unleashing their salvo would destroy the makteba. the question is, why did the makteba let itself be hit? it's never happened in your lifetime, at least not for your makteba, but they are capable of movement. the albatross exist at light speed and have had a long time to perfect their technology. it's not practical and it's not cheap, but the infrastructure is there for the makteba, the moon itself, to travel at near-light speed. so why didn't it escape? was it pride, inability, or something else?
- as you've wandered the ruins, you've seen countless Last Standard cargo vessels, vultures picking the remains of the corpse. you've attacked them where you can, but sometimes the numbers are just too much. at the centre of the impact crater, you know that something is being built. but the walls have been built tall and strong, and your wing is still broken.
history:
"BEDIVERE, in ancient Cradle legend, was one of the sole survivors of that gruesome battle, where hero-king and usurper alike were slain. LANCELOT turned his back on his kingdom, and KING ARTHUR's body was carried away to a place far away. You, too, must survive, no matter how lonely it becomes. Then, maybe one day, the ones you are waiting for will return."

Recently on Ras Nova, rumors have been spreading about a strange mech with an unidentified Lancer in its cockpit, the ghost of an Albatross lost to time. Few have been able to communicate with him successfully. Contact with The Last Standard has been extremely violent; however, contact with The Aftermath has always been simply ignored. The ghost has most often been spotted around ruins of the fallen moon, but what the ghost does there is unknown to all parties.

This ghost is Quartz Albas, known by the callsign Bedivere.

Quartz was a Loyal Wing, an Albatross of high renown: the moon that fell upon Ras Nova was his detachment's Makteba. He was one of the youngest Petrels in history to graduate to a Loyal Wing, at least in his Makteba. On the last mission he was on, he was fatally wounded protecting the Petrels under his wing. His detachment, wherever they found themselves in the universe, decided to send him back to their Makteba as an attempt to save him, as the detachment did not have the specialized equipment nor the proper mechanics to keep him stable.

Quartz awoke from hazy stasis confused. Where was he? Where were his comrades? Did his cadets make it out safely? The answers he got were strange and alarming: that he was on the planet Ras Nova, once known as Ark IV-Φ. His detachment was now so distant, the chances of him ever reuniting with them were close to null. Whatever allies he had on his Makteba were now few and far between, as the moon that held the Makteba had been destroyed by The Last Standard's Thousand-Arrow Protocol just a month before he descended upon Ras Nova.

For some time, Quartz was hidden from both The Aftermath and The Last Standard, as he got his bearings back. His rescuers were descendants of retired Albatross that descended onto the planet, and their connections allowed them to quietly nurse Quartz back up and provide him while hiding his identity and equipment. However, Quartz departed not long after he was able to move.

After all, it was The Last Standard that destroyed his home, and the Albatross will not go unavenged.

O sorrowful seabird with severed wing, displaced and lost,

No nest to return to, nor kin to welcome you home.

Let wrath strengthen you, as you wage war on the endless storm.

systems.flavorDescription: Packed into sealed, self-contained cylinders, IPS-N’s “Roland Rounds” are high-explosive anti-armor charges built for kinetic weapons of any mech-scale caliber. Loaded in place of inert kinetic ammunition, a Roland HE/AA shell increases the efficacy and destructive power of any weapon it is fired from.
The GMS Type-3 Projected Shield traps and denies incoming projectiles by projecting an aggressive, superpositional anti-ballistic barrier.
By installing additional armor plating, redundant firing circuits, and enhanced insulation to magazines the longevity of a frame’s armaments can be greatly enhanced.

weapon.flavorDescription:
Much like GMS mechs, GMS weapons are reliable galactic standards, made using interchangeable parts and built to withstand almost any conditions. There are three lines currently in production.
The Type-III (T-3) line is made up of heavy weapons, ordnance, and other exotic, specialized, or massive weapons. A broad classification, the T-3 range includes conventional-kinetic anti-materiel rifles, super-rapid cycling pulse rifles, missile racks, cannons, and drone nexuses – “hive”style launchers that serve as miniature factory, hangar, and deployment systems for portable drones. The classification also includes the fearsome “segment knife”, a system that uses flash-printing to produce disposable edged weapons in a vicinity around the user.

The IPS-N hand cannon is a licensed version of GMS’s Type-I Pistol, adapted for a much heavier caliber. This modification requires the belt-fed system of the GMS build to be swapped for a cylinder or magazine-based system, depending on the specific model of hand cannon.

Much like GMS mechs, GMS weapons are reliable galactic standards, made using interchangeable parts and built to withstand almost any conditions. There are three lines currently in production.
The Type-II (T-2) line displays GMS’s proprietary “charged” melee weapons and energy weapons. T-2 charged melee weapons are structurally similar to GMS’s T-1 melee weapons, though built with different materials to tolerate the intense heat generated by their projected plasma sheaths. These sheaths can be toggled on or off, depending on the needs of the pilot. GMS’s T-2 energy weapons, like their T-1 kinetics, are sturdy tools with predictable power scaling, minimal particle scattering, and consistent performance ranges. They feature universal ports allowing them to accept a variety of power sources, from hardline cabling through to “magazine” style power packs.

weapons.flavorDescription: These weapons were made using pre-Union alloys and technology, and might be anything from industrial-era steel swords through to stone axes. While they remain widely used on some worlds, archaic weapons used by pilots are usually relics, heirlooms, or ceremonial weapons.
Medium signature weapons are assault rifles, shotguns, pack-fed lasers, or disruption guns.

gear.flavorDescription: This kit contains many essentials for surviving in hostile environments: a rebreather, water filters, hardsuit patches, backup thermals, a bivouac kit, and so on.

Dataplating is a general term for any comm-linked jewelry, subdermal netting, wearable jaw, brow, or maxillary plates, etc., that allows subvocal communication and persistent heads-up and augmented reality displays without wearing a helm. Dataplates can quickly translate nearly any language, and allow users to communicate with each other all but silently.

A powerful electronic scope that provides high-resolution magnification up to two miles, and automatically adjusts its reticle for wind, gravity, and pressure. Smart scopes can project their field of vision and all data to the HUD of any networked user. They can also pair with other thermal, optical, or simulated-vision devices to further enhance targeting.
